title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this grant is to obtain an understanding of tiger population trends in Thung Yai East Wildlife Sanctuary (TYE) and Thung Yai West (TYW) and the impact upon those trends of threats emanating from seven villages in TYE so that appropriate management actions may be developed. Specifically the Recipient will: (1) conduct a camera trap survey in TYE using about 50 camera trap points at 4-5 kilometers spacing, placed in two blocks of 25 trapping points per block and conducted over a 2 month period; (2) conduct a similar camera trap survey in TYW; and (3) undertake a rigorous analysis of the threats emanating from the seven villages that are found in the northwestern valley that runs through TYE by recording data in three areas on human activities, sign of target wildlife species, livestock grazing, tiger predation, location of poaching, poaching patterns.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Postal Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build local capacity for long-term landscape genetic monitoring, working with local wildlife biologists, patrol rangers and veterinary and forestry students from local universities. Project will provide guidelines and promote rigorous standards for noninvasive genetic sampling. Grantee will assess the genetic diversity of elephants, determine whether there is genetic discontinuity within and among elephant populations across the western landscape, and test whether confinement of elephant populations into small and isolated protected areas disrupt the social structure and long-range dispersal patterns which are critical to population viability. Field sampling will be carried out in western Thailand

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to, (1) Collect fecal-DNA samples and conduct capture-mark-recapture analysis to estimate a baseline Asian elephant population in Kuiburi National Park; Fecal DNA will be analyzed in Nepal; (2) Facilitate the adaptive management of Asian elephant conservation activities within Kuiburi National Park through providing a robust Asian elephant population estimate against which the effectiveness of conservation interventions within, and around, the protected area can be measured; (3) Promote fecal DNA capture-mark-recapture analysis as the primary framework for Asian elephant monitoring in the Dawna Tennaserim Landscape through production and dissemination of a minimum of two conservation resources: a Thai language manual and a peer-reviewed scientific publication.

title.narrative: Conservation of tigers and tiger prey in Thailands Western Forest Complex through law enforcement and education

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring the population of tigers back to its natural carrying capacity in this World Heritage Site. This will be done by: (1) maintaining the Smart patrol system in TYW by (a) training park rangers, (b) replacing broken GPSs and digital cameras with new ones, (c) supporting ration costs and other important field supplies, (d) examining data collected for errors and quality and enter data into MIST database, (e) arranging monthly meetings with heads of the patrol teams and facilitate the meeting, (f) preparing monthly reports using MIST and make them useful for management improvement, (g) distributing the cost for patrol rations and providing other morale boosting supplies and materials for patrol teams, and (h) measuring progress using functions in MIST software to evaluate patrol efforts and effectiveness in reduction of threats; (2) publishing 1,000 copies of the 2-volume manual titled Nature Education for Conservation of Endangered Wildlife Species; (3) presenting a training workshop on the manuals for school teachers and a second workshop for local NGOs and government; and (4) setting up the International House of Conservation at Kasetsart University to initially work with about 60 students by establishing the following (a) necessary room renovations, (b) 10 stations of visual and sound labs (computer sets and head phones) for self-study of international conservation projects, (c) a small meeting room (10 seats) for small group teaching, seminar, and group discussion among the students, and (d) cabinets for DVDs of conservation and nature programs in WEFCOM and around the world, books, brochures, reports, and papers from international conservation projects including WEFCOM, and reading corners for self-learning.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to develop a sustainable education program in Thailand addressing the conservation of Asian elephants that improves science literacy, and critical thinking skills in Thai students. Through the project the following will be accomplished: 1) Expand TEIs 10 lesson elephant-centered educational curriculum to 20 Thai schools (10-15 year olds/5th-8th grades), 10 located in Bangkok and 10 in Kanchanaburi. 2) Recruit and train Mahidol university students (recent undergraduates and Masters level graduates in Conservation Biology) to implement TEI curriculum in schools.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to improve protection for tigers in the Forest Complex. This will be done by: 1. presenting an intense two-week ranger-led enforcement team leader course using PROTECT training materials to develop skilled enforcement leaders for the PAs; 2. holding a SMART software course for park based mangers (SMART Transitional Training) and mentoring park management and rangers on the use of the data collection techniques and analysis of the data; 3. donating essential field equipment for use by the rangers while on patrol; 4. accompanying rangers on patrols, identifying gaps in the their adoption of new techniques, and providing follow-up support; 5.a) continuing to conduct regular camera trapping and patrol-based monitoring in Thap Lan and Pang Sida to fill existing survey gaps in the complex, b) continuing long-term monitoring in areas with strong tiger presence, and c) providing on-the-job monitoring training to rangers; 6). organizing a 2 day workshop at Dong Yai Wildlife Sanctuary for 30 teachers from 15 schools adjacent to the complex on the design and implementation of conservation education modules and then tasking the trained teachers with developing and implementing a 1 week module at their home schools on local wildlife and the environment; and 7) sustaining support for community environmental patrols and training patrol members and planners within the community NGO.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Southeast area of the Western Forest Conservation Complex (WEFCOM), Kanchanaburi province, west Thailand

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to enable the recovery and protection of tigers and tiger prey in Salakpra Wildlife Sanctuary. This will be done by networking with the Department of National Parks and other NGO tiger researchers to develop the capacity in the Salakpra Zoological Society of London (ZSL)/Elephant Conservation Network (ECN) team and relevant rangers to undertake basic tiger surveys; acquiring baseline data on tiger and tiger prey distribution and densities in Salakpra; and supporting the integration of tiger survey findings into the Salakpra patrol system...Specifically, this will include: 1) recruiting a project assistant; 2) providing equipment to the tiger team needed to implement the project; 3) arranging a five day field course on tiger and tiger prey survey techniques in Huai Kha Khaeng for the tiger team and relevant rangers; 4) carrying out a 4 day study trip for the tiger team (about 12 people) to another tiger site (e.g. Thap Lan NP) that uses similar tiger survey techniques to those planned for this project; 5) implementing the camera-trap surveys for tigers; 6) implementing the ungulate surveys to measure ungulate occupancy; 7) logging the data from the camera-traps and foot surveys into the database; 8) analyzing the data on a regular basis so it is available for patrol planning and deployment; 9) providing feedback at Salakpras Protected Area Committee management meetings to ensure that findings of this project are integrated into the Salakpra management and protection system; and 10) organizing a tiger conservation network gathering at the end of the project to share findings with project advisors and their tiger team colleagues in order to discuss future collaborations and what next? ."

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to enable the recovery and protection of tigers and tiger prey in Salakpra Wildlife Sanctuary. This will be done by networking with the Department of National Parks and other NGO tiger researchers to develop the capacity in the Salakpra Zoological Society of London (ZSL)/Elephant Conservation Network (ECN) team and relevant rangers to undertake basic tiger surveys; acquiring baseline data on tiger and tiger prey distribution and densities in Salakpra; and supporting the integration of tiger survey findings into the Salakpra patrol system...Specifically, this will include: 1) recruiting a project assistant; 2) providing equipment to the tiger team needed to implement the project; 3) arranging a five day field course on tiger and tiger prey survey techniques in Huai Kha Khaeng for the tiger team and relevant rangers; 4) carrying out a 4 day study trip for the tiger team (about 12 people) to another tiger site (e.g. Thap Lan NP) that uses similar tiger survey techniques to those planned for this project; 5) implementing the camera-trap surveys for tigers; 6) implementing the ungulate surveys to measure ungulate occupancy; 7) logging the data from the camera-traps and foot surveys into the database; 8) analyzing the data on a regular basis so it is available for patrol planning and deployment; 9) providing feedback at Salakpras Protected Area Committee management meetings to ensure that findings of this project are integrated into the Salakpra management and protection system; and 10) organizing a tiger conservation network gathering at the end of the project to share findings with project advisors and their tiger team colleagues in order to discuss future collaborations and what next? ."

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to promote police-led cross-border intelligence sharing between governments on wildlife trafficking particularly tigers and rhinos and thereby increasing successful arrests of high-level traders. This will be done by supporting initiation of a dedicated law enforcement and intelligence analysis unit the LEEO (Law Enforcement Extension Office) and providing essential equipment, hiring an intelligence analyst to work with a seconded, dedicated Royal Thai Police (RTP) officer; having that RTP officer collect, analyze, develop and distribute information/intelligence as needed among the ASEAN WEN countries; providing expert guidance to those countries; and developing streamlined and effective training and networking events.

title.narrative: Conservation of Tigers and Tiger Prey in Thailands Western Forest Complex through Law Enforcement and Education, Year 7

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to maintain the Smart patrol system in Thung Yai West Wildlife Sanctuary (TYW) at a high level of intensity and coverage; to improve awareness of local communities and schools through presentation of nature education campaigns on tiger and wildlife conservation in key schools and communities close to Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary (HKK); and to improve capacity of future protected area managers at Kasetsart University to be ready to run protected areas by training them in operation of the Smart patrol system and wildlife population monitoring. This will be done by: (1) supporting operation of 17 patrol teams (5-6 rangers/team) in TYW by providing technical support, equipment including GPSs and digital cameras, patrol ration costs, and other camping supplies; (2) conducting 3 nature education campaigns, using the "Manual of Nature Education for Conservation of Endangered Wildlife Species " for local school teachers, students, and villages near TYW; and (3) training 30 undergraduate wildlife students in the Department of Forest Biology, Faculty of Forestry, Kasetsart University on the Smart patrol system and tiger population monitoring systems in HKK.

title.narrative: Reinforcing frontline protection of Thailand's elephants: Strengthening reactive enforcement, monitoring, and community-led conservation in the Dong Phayayen-Khao Yai Forest Complex

description.narrative: This project aims to improve protection for Asian elephants in the Dong Phayayen-Khao Yai Forest Complex by developing systems and personnel to respond to and investigate enforcement situations, improve elephant monitoring systems, and empower community leaders in conservation activities. The recipient will: 1) provide training to Special Response Groups through a specialized PROTECT training course; 2) integrate SMART software into management activities; 3) conduct an investigations primer training course using the DETECT training material; 4) provide field equipment such as hammocks, sleeping bags, and compasses; 5) measure uptake of training information; 6) conduct regular camera-trap and patrol-based elephant monitoring; 7) provide administrative support to a local community-directed conservation group; 8) test, implement, and monitor effectiveness of human-elephant conflict (HEC) barriers such as beehive fences, and thorny and unpalatable plant species; and 9) train, support and mentor community-led environmental and HEC patrols. This project is the next step in institutionalizing patrol and HEC-mitigation activities to secure long-term protection of Asian elephants in this Forest Complex.

title.narrative: Elephant conservation and education campaigns and capacity strengthening of future protected area managers in the Western Forest Complex, Thailand - Year 7

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to maintain the SMART patrol system in Thung Yai West Wildlife Sanctuary (TYW) at its current intensity and coverage and to build a volunteer network in Huai Kha Khaeng (HKK) from existing volunteer groups and university conservation clubs. Project activities will include: 1) conduct follow-up monitoring with 17 patrol teams in TYW by providing technical support, refresher training, equipment, and patrol rations; 2) entry, review, and analysis of patrol data into the SMART database; 3) prepare and distribute monthly SMART reports; and 4) build a volunteer network by selecting a group of 40 volunteers, including local school teachers, NGOs, and Thai university students to participate in a 5-day wildlife conservation workshop at HKK. This project will contribute to the protection and increase of the wild population of Asian elephants in Thailands Western Forest Complex, a UNESCO Natural World Heritage Site.

title.narrative: Law enforcement monitoring and human-elephant conflict mitigation in Kaeng Krachan National Park, Thailand - Year 11

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to secure the long-term conservation of the wild elephant population and its habitat in Kaeng Krachan National Park by increasing the effectiveness of protection efforts and reducing human-elephant conflict (HEC) in the region. Project activities will include: 1) support of law enforcement monitoring using SMART software by providing training to guard teams, and field equipment, rations, and supplies for foot patrols; 2) reduction of HEC by promoting and monitoring standard HEC mitigation methods in local and extension of the semi-permanent fence in Huai Sad Yai; and 3) expansion of elephant conservation education directed at villagers from four HEC target sites, follow-up activities with three secondary schools, and an education campaign for tourists. This project will lead to more effective patrolling and law enforcement activities in the Park, better provisioned, trained, and motivated staff who are capable of addressing the threat of elephant poaching gangs, and reduced retaliatory elephant deaths.

title.narrative: Conservation of tigers and tiger prey in Thailands Western Forest Complex (WEFCOM) through law enforcement and education-Year 8

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring the tiger population back to its natural carrying capacity in the World Heritage Site, including Huai Kha Khaeng (HKK) and Thung Yai (TY) Wildlife Sanctuaries. The project will maintain the SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrol system, provide continuous training and necessary equipment, to ensure a strong law enforcement staff to protect tigers, tiger-prey and other wildlife against poaching. Project will also build a conservation volunteer network at Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary.

title.narrative: Extending a multifaceted tiger conservation approach from Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary to Thung Yai East Wildlife Sanctuary, Thailand

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to combine management, monitoring and applied research activities developed in Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary (HKK) to a portion of the Thung Yai East Wildlife Sanctuary (TYE), in order to increase the number and distribution of tigers in TYE in areas where tigers and tiger prey density is below carrying capacity due to human activities. Increased patrolling, camera trapping, radio collaring of female tigers and subadult young, and local participation in patrolling will be part of a coordinated effort to better understand why tigers and prey abundance are low in areas where they should occur at higher densities.

title.narrative: Reducing threats to pangolins through strengthening law enforcement capacity and developing ecological monitoring protocols

description.narrative: this project will develop methodologies for the collection of baseline data on the abundance, distribution and habitat selections of the Sunda Pangolins. This data will be analyzed using SMART and the ecological monitoring plug-in. The analysis of data will be used to create a targeted patrolling effort that will ensure the protection of critical pangolin habitat and monitoring of poaching hotspots. In addition, community survey data on pangolin poaching, consumption, and trade will be collected as part of outreach activities.

title.narrative: Protecting Asian elephants through the integration of ecological research and conflict mitigation in the Salakpra Conservation Landscape, Thailand

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to contribute to the conservation of the Asian elephant in the Salakpra Conservation Landscape by enhancing their movement and reducing human-elephant conflict (HEC) events through the adaptation of sustainable land use plans, conflict mitigation, and conservation management programs. Specific activities will include: 1) development of land use/cover maps for the Salakpra Conservation Landscape; 2) collection of elephant ecological data; 3) identification of elephant dispersal routes and high value habitats; 4) development of a landscape scale habitat management plan; 5) training of community members to collect crop-raiding data; 6) compilation and analysis of crop-raiding data into a database; 7) convening quarterly community engagement meetings to share results, develop land use plans, and identify HEC mitigation techniques collaboratively; 8) implementation of crop-raiding mitigation techniques and analyses of their effectiveness; and 9) develop statistical models to identify drivers of crop raiding. This project will lead to improved conservation of Asian elephants in Thailand by producing an evidence-based landscape scale habitat management plan and the utilization of implementation of effective HEC mitigation techniques in the Salakpra Conservation Landscape.

title.narrative: Determining the Population Status and Threats to Tiger Population Stability in Southern WEFCOM

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the viability of the tiger population in the Salakpra Conservation Landscape (SCL) by understanding distribution and dispersal patterns, as well as to reduce the threats to both tigers and ungulate species through improved conservation management practices, enhanced law enforcement and the facilitation of collaborations between all stakeholders. The project objectives are as follows: (1) Determine ecological baselines for tiger populations, and distribution and abundance of ungulate species within Erawan National Park (ENP) and Western Sri Nakarin National Park (SNNP); (2) Reduce threats to tigers, ungulate species and their habitat in the western SCL by 20% in 2017, by conducting a comprehensive threat assessment for the western sector of the SCL, establishing a standardized law enforcement system in the western SCL, training protected area (PA) rangers to collect threat and wildlife sighting on patrol using Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) model, training PA staff in the use of SMART software, tactical planning, setting up standardized queries and reports and structures, creating a SMART database for individual PA and the entire SCL, and operationalizing SMART across the SCL.

title.narrative: Determining the Population Status and Threats to Tiger Population Stability in Southern WEFCOM

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the viability of the tiger population in the Salakpra Conservation Landscape (SCL) by understanding distribution and dispersal patterns, as well as to reduce the threats to both tigers and ungulate species through improved conservation management practices, enhanced law enforcement and the facilitation of collaborations between all stakeholders. The project objectives are as follows: (1) Determine ecological baselines for tiger populations, and distribution and abundance of ungulate species within Erawan National Park (ENP) and Western Sri Nakarin National Park (SNNP); (2) Reduce threats to tigers, ungulate species and their habitat in the western SCL by 20% in 2017, by conducting a comprehensive threat assessment for the western sector of the SCL, establishing a standardized law enforcement system in the western SCL, training protected area (PA) rangers to collect threat and wildlife sighting on patrol using Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) model, training PA staff in the use of SMART software, tactical planning, setting up standardized queries and reports and structures, creating a SMART database for individual PA and the entire SCL, and operationalizing SMART across the SCL.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Conservation of Tigers through Law Enforcement and Education Campaign in the Western Forest Complex, Thailand Year 9-11

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring tigers back to their natural carrying capacity in the Western Forest Complex, a World Heritage Site. The project has the following objectives: (1) To maintain the Smart patrol system in Thung Yai West to the current intensity and coverage, provide rangers refresher training, examine Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) data, evaluate patrol effectiveness and threat reduction; (2) To build a volunteer network from existing volunteer groups and conservation clubs in key universities to conduct nature education activities in Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary (HKK), repair "Home of the Tiger Nature Trail " provide training on use of the Nature Education Manual for Wildlife Conservation, provide training on designing and producing wildlife conservation campaign materials; and (3) To train undergraduate wildlife students from Kasetsart University on SMART patrol and wildlife monitoring techniques in HKK, provide an overview of the importance of SMART patrol system to protect endangered species, train students on use of GPS patrolling and data collection, provide students an overview of the occupancy survey technique and conducting the field occupancy survey, and other important field methods.

title.narrative: Lar gibbon protection in the Western Forest Complex, Thailand

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect and potentially increase the population of lar gibbon in the Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary. The main objectives of this project are to maintain the SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrol system in Huai Kha Khaeng to the current intensity and coverage, and to establish a baseline population estimate for lar gibbon in HKK. The following activities will be accomplished: (a) conduct close follow-up monitoring with 22 patrol teams (5 rangers/team) in Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary by providing technical support, refresher training, necessary equipment, patrol ration costs, and other morale boosting activities, (b) conduct a population estimate by dispatching teams of three observers to selected listening areas that exhibit topographical features known to be of preference to lar gibbon, and carefully selecting listening posts that provide optimal data collection based on surrounding topography, and (c) after five months of data collection there will be a period of data entry and statistical analysis.

title.narrative: REDUCING DEMAND FOR PANGOLINS THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED SOCIAL MARKETING

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COUNTER WILDLIFE TRAFFICKING FROM PANGOLIN RANGE STATES IN AFRICA AND ASIA TO CHINA, BY LAYING THE FOUNDATIONS FOR REDUCING CONSUMER DEMAND FOR PANGOLIN IN THREE CHINESE PROVINCES IDENTIFIED AS BEING MAJOR HUBS FOR CONSUMPTION OF ILLEGALLY TRADED WILDLIFE. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE ALL EIGHT SPECIES OF PANGOLIN BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACT OF CONSUMER DEMAND IN CHINA WHICH DRIVES POACHING AND TRAFFICKING IN PANGOLIN RANGE STATES. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 SELECTING PRECISE BEHAVIOURS TO CHANGE 2 IDENTIFYING BARRIERS AND BENEFITS TO DESIRED BEHAVIOURS 3 DEVELOPING STRATEGIES TO CHANGE BEHAVIOURS 4 PILOTING THE BEHAVIOUR CHANGE STRATEGIES AND 5 BROAD-SCALE IMPLEMENTATION.THE SCOPE OF WORK WAS CHANGED TO SHIFT PROPOSED ACTIVITIES FROM CHINA TO THAILAND IN SPRING 2020. THE SHIFT TO THAILAND WAS IN RESPONSE TO THE RECIPIENT BEING UNABLE TO REGISTER TO LEGALLY OPERATE IN CHINA DUE TO NEW LAWS THAT WERE PUT IN PLACE AFTER THE GRANT WASAWARDED. THE RECIPIENT WILL CARRY OUT THE ORIGINAL ACTIVITIES IN THAILAND WITH A CONTINUED FOCUS ON THE SAME TARGET POPULATION CONSUMERS OF PANGOLIN PRODUCTS . CARRYING OUT THIS WORK IN THAILAND IS PART OF THE RECIPIENT S EXISTING PROGRAM STRATEGY IN THAILAND AND THE RECIPIENT IS ALREADY CARRYING OUT SIMILAR, ONGOING ACTIVITIES.

title.narrative: Effective protection for Thailands last tigers: Fortifying conservation through enforcement,.monitoring, and community-led outreach in the Dong Phayayen-Khao Yai Forest complex

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the survival of tigers in Thailands Dong Pahayayen-Khao Yai (DPKY) Forest Complex. The project will support the following objectives: (1) Expand community support for the conservation and protection of tigers in Thailands DPKY Forest Complex, by expanding conservation education, awareness, and networking; (2) Improve strategic management and enforcement capacity in DPKY, by establishing a central strategic management and operations center for DPKY, expanding Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) software and support, and providing on-the-job training and mentoring for Rapid Response Unit (Hasadin); and (3) Enhance wildlife monitoring to augment park managements understanding of tiger abundance, distribution and use of the DPKY Forest Complex landscape, by filling data gaps through improvements in tiger monitoring.

title.narrative: Lar gibbon protection in Thailands Western Forest Complex

description.narrative: Lar gibbons are Endangered. The Western Forest Complex (WEFCOM) is one of the last strongholds for this species in Asia. Poaching and habitat loss are major threats to lar gibbon in WEFCOM, and to mitigate this threat WCS-Thailand is working closely with the Government of Thailand to train and equip rangers to protect the lar gibbons of WEFCOM. Lar gibbons are especially sensitive to illegal logging and poaching pressure as they are canopy dwellers, rarely setting foot on the forest floor. Project objectives include: (1) To maintain the SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrol system in Huai Kha Khaeng (HKK) to the current intensity and coverage, and support 22 patrol teams (5 rangers/team) in HKK by providing technical assistance, refresher training, necessary equipment, and patrol ration costs; and (2) To build on previously acquired lar gibbon survey data and establish a baseline population estimate for lar gibbon in the southern area of HKK.

title.narrative: Coordinating Civil Society Responses to increasing HEC issues in Thailand

description.narrative: The Dong Phayayen-Khao Yai landscape (DPKY) supports one of the largest contiguous and growing elephant populations in Thailand. However, it remains threatened by encroachment, poaching, and human-elephant conflict (HEC). The goal of this project is to strengthen protection for elephants in DPKY and transfer and replicate effective HEC solutions to HEC hotspots in southeast Thailand. Project objectives include: 1) empower a civil society network to share grassroots HEC solutions; 2) advance enforcement and training capacity for the Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation; and 3) improve wildlife monitoring capacity in partnership with stakeholders. Specific project activities include: 1) strengthen civil society capacity to monitor, mitigate, and report HEC; 2) research and implement innovative HEC mitigation techniques and transfer these skills to select sites in southeast Thailand and convene CSO workshops in order to network, and enhance awareness and responsiveness; 3) support on-the-job-training and mentoring capacity for Rapid Response Units; 4) support Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) implementation; 5) expand elephant monitoring and data analysis to enhance government planning and management capacities. This project will contribute to the conservation of wild Asian elephants in the DPKY forest complex and transfer those methods to other landscapes in Thailand.

title.narrative: Living with elephants: Improving human-elephant coexistence in Thailands Western Forest Complex Corridor

description.narrative: The goal of this two-year project is to promote coexistence of Asian elephants and humans (HECx) by working with the government and communities in the Western Forest Complex (WEFCOM) of Thailand, a mosaic of protected areas (PA) and regionally significant elephant conservation landscape. Project objectives include: 1) set baselines for the distribution, composition and occupancy of elephants and livestock in PAs, with a monthly monitoring program in place to inform an adaptive HECx approach; 2) build upon a socio-economic and HEC database through surveys and HEC monitoring and conduct annual meetings and awareness raising in two villages to develop a long-term HECx plan; and 3) implementation of elephant early warning systems in two villages. Project activities include: 1) conduct camera trap (CT) surveys to understand spatio-temporal distribution of elephants as well as livestock incursions into the PAs; 2) conduct CT surveys at watering holes and mineral licks in the PAs, as well as entry/exits used by elephants in four villages; 3) build a long-term individual ID database for elephants; 4) provide an elephant ID guide and training for PA managers and staff; and 5) analyze CT data on species movement and integrate it into mitigation strategies.

title.narrative: Rapid Nesting and Threats Assessments for the Recovery of Hawksbill Nesting in the Gulf of Thailand

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to identify remnant hawksbill nesting population along 500 km of Thailand coast in which to establish community based conservation programs. The intent of this project is to protect hawksbill nests and nesting females from poaching. Activities include: Year 1; (1) Synthesize all reported hawksbill nesting within past 5 years; (2) visit communities where nesting has been reported to confirm recent or current nesting and threats through interviews and conducting night time surveys; (3) during community visits document presence and sale of hawksbill shell and other sea turtle products; and (4) support 4 Thai representatives to participate in regional training workshop in Cambodia on sea turtle biology and conservation methods. Year 2: (1) conduct capacity building and training workshop for 16 participants from four Thai Provinces and additional representatives from Thai Navy and Dept. of Marine and Coastal Resources that are or will be involved in on ground nesting beach conservation projects.

title.narrative: PILOTING SYSTEMS OF INTELLIGENCE-LED WILDLIFE CRIME PREVENTION IN THE SOUTHEASTERN WESTERN FOREST COMPLEX THAILAND

description.narrative: Forests across Southeast Asia are slowly being emptied of mammals, reptiles, and birds to fuel demand for status symbols, traditional medicine, and exotic pets. The purpose of this project is to trial systems and processes that better equip enforcement rangers and protected area staff to counter wildlife trafficking in three of five protected areas (PAs) in the southeastern section of the Western Forest Complex (sWEFCOM) in Thailand. This project is intended to conserve threatened species including the Indochinese tiger, Asian elephant, and Sunda pangolin by increasing the Department of National Parks (DNP) and local law enforcement agencies capacity to disrupt wildlife poaching and trafficking. Specific activities of this two-year grant include: (1) building capacity and systems to better aggregate, manage, and analyze multiple information streams on illegal wildlife trade through the use of a single intelligence platform across sWEFCOM; (2) formalizing sWEFCOM action plans for combating wildlife crime within each PA and build cross-PA relationships necessary to carry out targeted LE interventions; and (3) promoting additional information-sharing outside of the PA network and facilitate collaboration between other national law enforcement agencies to develop trusted relationships and ongoing cooperation in combating wildlife crime.

title.narrative: Understanding Elephant Behavior: A Novel Approach to Mitigating Human/Elephant Conflict in Kanchanaburi, Thailand

description.narrative: This two-year project undertakes a novel study that will identify individual differences in wild Asian elephant behavior and construct a personality profile for crop-raiding elephants in Salakapra Wildlife Sanctuary, Kanchanaburi, Thailand. Comparative elephant behavioral will be collected from watchtowers on the border of the protected area (PA) and adjacent crop fields, and at watering holes as elephants prepare to raid crops, are raiding or human-elephant conflict (HEC), or are safely inside the PA. Food-rewarding puzzle boxes will be installed at watering holes in the PA to observe how differences in elephant behavior and personality are exhibited in a task requiring innovation and problem-solving. These behavioral data will inform the development of a behavioral/personality profile of crop-raiding elephants. If dominance, aggression, affiliation, innovation, problem-solving, emotional state, and risk aversion can be correlated with propensity to crop-raid new non-fear-based HEC mitigation strategies can be developed. This work has important implications for understanding why certain elephants crop raid, and how mitigation strategies can account for elephant needs and behavior and change their decision-making. Ultimately, this project will work to prevent HEC before it begins ensuring that mitigation strategies are long-term rather than temporary fixes to a growing problem.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF TIGERS THROUGH LAW ENFORCEMENT AND PREY POPULATION RECOVERY IN DONG PHAYAYEN KHAO YAI FOREST COMPLEX, THAILAND

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to solidify the recovery of tigers in Thailand's Dong Phayayen-Khao Yai (DPKY) Forest Complex and secure the dispersal to connected environs including Bantaey Chhmar Protected Landscape (BCPL) in Cambodia. Project objectives are as follows: (1) Improve strategic enforcement in DPKY and BCPL; (2) Expand monitoring to increase understanding of tiger population dynamics and dispersal to connected habitat; and (3) Expand wider support for the conservation of tigers, prey and biodiversity in DPKY, BCPL and the Dangrak ecological corridor.

title.narrative: REPLACEMENT AWARDS FOR FY2019 - LAR GIBBON PROTECTION IN THAILAND'S WESTERN FOREST COMPLEX

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect and potentially increase the population of lar gibbon in the Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary (HKK). The improved patrol system in Thailand is called Smart Patrols and refers to a system of patrols that have the following characteristics: they are well-equipped with proper uniforms, high-quality field gear and good rations; they are well trained in physical fitness, ways to handle arrests and other encounters in the field and Thai law around ranger patrols; they collect data on threats, patrol routes and wildlife in a systematic fashion (using software such as MIST and its successor SMART-Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) and use this information in an adaptive management framework; patrolling happens at a high density over time and geographic space to ensure both deterrence, detection and capacity to respond to threats. Project objects are to, (1) maintain the Smart patrol system in Huai Kha Khaeng to the current intensity and coverage, and (2) implement a gibbon monitoring system in HKK where threats have been recorded

title.narrative: CONSERVING THE CRITICAL ASIAN ELEPHANT POPULATIONS OF HUAI KHA KHAENG AND KAENG KRACHAN WORLD HERITAGE SITES THROUGH IMPROVED SMART PATROL AND HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT MITIGATION, YEAR 16-18.

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to recover Asian elephants in Thailands Western Forest Complex landscape through effective protection and collaborative human-elephant conflict (HEC) mitigation in World Heritage Sites of Huai Kha Khaeng National Park (HKK) and Kaeng Krachan National Park (KKNP). Project objectives are to: (1) strengthen the SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) Patrol System in HKK and KKNP through training, technical support, and monitoring performance; (2) reduce HEC by promoting standard mitigation methods along with monitoring the effectiveness of those methods to examine temporal and spatial changes in elephant crop-raiding behavior; (3) estimate elephant population size in HKK and KKNP; and (4) expand conservation education programs to promote elephant conservation and HEC mitigation schemes to local communities, and improve cooperation among park staff, local communities, and other stakeholders. Project activities are to: (1) conduct follow-up monitoring with 43 patrol teams (5-6 rangers/team) per year in HKK and KKNP and provide technical support, refresher training, necessary equipment, and activities to support morale; (2) train 65 park rangers per year; (3) setup a new SMART Patrol Center in a new building at KKNP to improve its capacity and operation; (4) maintain an existing semi.permanent HEC mitigation fence; (5) monitor HEC effectiveness at HKK and KKNP; (6) develop and promote a real-time HEC warning system to support night response teams; (7) provide necessary equipment, fuel, and ration costs for three HEC night.response teams; (8) use DISTANCE program sampling and dung counts in HKK and KKNP to determine elephant population sizes; (9) conduct nature education campaigns for 15 schools reaching 600 students; and (10) improve and operate the Elephant Conservation Information Center providing updated facilities and information to all visitors and stakeholders.

title.narrative: UNDERSTANDING ELEPHANT BEHAVIOR: A NOVEL APPROACH TO MITIGATING HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT IN KANCHANABURI, THAILAND 2. USING ELEPHANT PERSONALITY TO DEVELOP A CONFLICT MITIGATION TOOLKIT

description.narrative: THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO OUR KNOWLEDGE OF ELEPHANT BEHAVIOR AND TO THE STRATEGIES THAT REDUCE THREATS TO ELEPHANTS BY PREVENTING HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC) USING A UNIQUE, ELEPHANT CENTRIC APPROACH. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE DIRECT BENEFITS TO THE PEOPLE OF KANCHANABURI, THAILAND, AND CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE EDUCATION AND MENTORING PROGRAM FOR THE NEXT GENERATION OF THAI POLICYMAKERS AND SCIENTISTS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO REFINE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF PERSONALITY IN WILD ASIAN ELEPHANTS, INVESTIGATE HOW PERSONALITY TRAITS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH HEC, AND DETERMINE WAYS THAT MITIGATION STRATEGIES CAN BE IMPLEMENTED MORE EFFECTIVELY WHILE ACCOUNTING FOR ELEPHANT PERSONALITIES AND COGNITION. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) EXPAND THE FREQUENCY OF OBSERVATIONS FROM WATCHTOWERS TO MONITOR ELEPHANT INTERACTIONS WITH FARMERS AS ELEPHANTS APPROACH AND ENTER CROP FIELDS (2) OPTIMIZE COLLECTION OF VIDEOS TO GATHER BEHAVIOR AND ELEPHANT POPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC DATA (3) ASSIGN THE PERSONALITY TRAITS OF INNOVATION, NEOPHILIA, BOLDNESS, AND AGGRESSION TO INDIVIDUAL ELEPHANTS BOTH IN AND AROUND SALAKPRA WILDLIFE SANCTUARY (4) SUPPORT FARMERS AND PARK RANGERS IN THEIR DAILY WORK AND ENGAGEMENT WITH THE PROJECT (5) COMPILE AND SHARE WITH FARMERS THE PERSONALITY PROFILES FOR ELEPHANTS OBSERVED IN MAE PLA SOI (MPS) AND THA MA NO

title.narrative: UNDERSTANDING ELEPHANT BEHAVIOR: A NOVEL APPROACH TO MITIGATING HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT IN KANCHANABURI, THAILAND 2. USING ELEPHANT PERSONALITY TO DEVELOP A CONFLICT MITIGATION TOOLKIT

description.narrative: This project will contribute to our knowledge of elephant behavior and to the strategies that reduce threats to elephants by preventing human-elephant conflict (HEC) using a unique, elephant-centric approach. The project will provide direct benefits to the people of Kanchanaburi, Thailand, and create a comprehensive education and mentoring program for the next generation of Thai policymakers and scientists. This project aims to refine our understanding of personality in wild Asian elephants, investigate how personality traits are associated with HEC, and determine ways that mitigation strategies can be implemented more effectively while accounting for elephant personalities and cognition. Project objectives are to: (1) expand the frequency of observations from watchtowers to monitor elephant interactions with farmers as elephants approach and enter crop fields; (2) optimize collection of videos to gather behavior and elephant population demographic data; (3) assign the personality traits of innovation, neophilia, boldness, and aggression to individual elephants both in and around Salakpra Wildlife Sanctuary; (4) support farmers and park rangers in their daily work and engagement with the project; (5) compile and share with farmers the personality profiles for elephants observed in Mae Pla Soi (MPS) and Tha Ma Now (TMN) village crop fields, using data from observational and experimental approaches; (6) design a mitigation toolkit using the elephants identified from one TMN crop field to assess the toolkits effectiveness; (7) create strategic toolkits for all other farmers working in and around field sites in MPS and TMN; (8) implement a novel elephant deterrence technique using olfactory cues and evaluate associations between personality and reactions to olfactory deterrents; (9) implement olfactory cue mitigation surrounding one MPS crop field and assess changes in elephant presence and behavior; (10) collaborate with Mahidol Universitys conservation bio

description.narrative: This project will support the Kouprey Express and the Wildlife Rapid Rescue Team.(WRRT) to reduce threats to Asian elephants and demand for ivory in Cambodia through an approach.that encompasses both wildlife law enforcement and demand reduction. The Kouprey Express.Environmental Education Program empowers youth and communities to make responsible decisions.regarding the sustainable management of natural resources; effect positive change; shifts in attitudes,.behaviors, and actions towards wildlife and their habitat; promote pride and grassroots action to protect.Asian elephants and other wildlife; and reduce consumption of ivory. The WRRT has an essential role in.combating wildlife crime in Cambodia and is responsible for the majority of wildlife crime investigations.in the country. This project will address threats to Asian elephants by: (1) directly combating the illegal.trade in ivory through focused investigations; (2) increasing governmental and institutional capacity; (3).empowering youth and communities to make responsible decisions and shifts in attitudes, behaviors, and.actions regarding the sustainable management of Cambodias wildlife and natural resources; and (4).promote pride and grassroots action to protect Asian elephants by reducing consumption for ivory..Project activities include: (1) build capacities of 750+ teachers and community leaders through three-day.workshops on core environmental concepts; (2) reach 10,500+ Cambodian youth through hands-on.environmental education and elephant conservation lessons, field trips to Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue.Center, and school visits; (3) conduct door-to-door outreach and 15+ Community Night Shows in rural.communities to share information about elephants, wildlife laws, and human-elephant conflict (HEC); (4).broadcast two animated public service announcements on television to promote the wildlife rescue hotline.and demand reduction messages; (5) use a targeted social media campaign in Khmer, English, and

title.narrative: IMPLEMENTING SWEFCOMS TIGER CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN: CONSOLIDATING BASELINES AND ADDRESSING CRITICAL THREATS

description.narrative: THE SCARCITY OF TIGER PREY IS CONSIDERED ONE OF THE KEY LIMITATIONS TO TIGER RECOVERY IN THE SOUTHERN WESTERN FOREST COMPLEX (SWEFCOM). THROUGH THIS PROJECT, PANTHERA PROPOSES TO ADDRESS THIS IN THE SALAKPRA CONSERVATION LANDSCAPE (SCL) THROUGH THREE DISTINCT LINES OF INTERVENTION. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) FILL SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL GAPS IN THE ECOLOGICAL MONITORING OF TIGERS AND PREY IN THE SCL (2) CONSOLIDATE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF PROBLEM-ORIENTED APPROACH TO WILDLIFE PROTECTION IN THE LANDSCAPE AND IDENTIFY NON-ENFORCEMENT-BASED INTERVENTIONS AND (3) DEVELOP AN ACTION PLAN TO REDUCE AND REGULATE LIVESTOCK GRAZING PROTECTED AREAS IN THE NORTHERN SCL.

title.narrative: IMPLEMENTING SWEFCOMS TIGER CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN: CONSOLIDATING BASELINES AND ADDRESSING CRITICAL THREATS

description.narrative: The scarcity of tiger prey is considered one of the key limitations to tiger recovery in the southern Western Forest Complex.(sWEFCOM). Through this project, Panthera proposes to address this in the Salakpra Conservation Landscape (SCL) through.three distinct lines of intervention. The purpose of this project is to (1) Fill spatial and temporal gaps in the ecological monitoring.of tigers and prey in the SCL; (2) Consolidate the implementation of problem-oriented approach to wildlife protection in the.landscape and identify non-enforcement-based interventions; and (3) Develop an action plan to reduce and regulate livestock.grazing protected areas in the northern SCL.

title.narrative: DISPERSAL: A KEY TO REFILING SOUTHEAST ASIA S LARGEST TIGER LANDSCAPE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) Understand tiger dispersal potential in the Western Forest Complex (WEFCOM) using a.landscape model developed to integrate dispersal movements, predict tiger and prey occupancy and identify areas for.management; (2) Create a tiger data database at Khao Nang Ram Research Station for the period 2007 to present to establish a.common identification system linking collared tiger IDs from multiple projects and incorporate into an existing WEFCOM spatial.database composed of the probability of habitat occupancy by tigers and their primary prey; (3) Develop and conduct conservation.education workshops at nine key Karen villages in Thung Yai East and West to build a program to increase community.conservation and reduce subsistence hunting; and (4) Develop and conduct two workshops with protected area chiefs, regional.DNP research staff, local and international NGOs to create a strategic plan to expand the distribution of tiger breeding habitat to.the 63% of WEFCOM where tigers are not currently breeding.

title.narrative: THE COMEBACK OF THE INDOCHINESE TIGER IN THAILAND'S DONG PHAYAYEN FOREST COMPLEX AND BEYOND, SAFEGUARDING A RECOVERY POPULATION OF INDOCHINESE TIGERS AND REESTABLISHING ITS WIDER HISTORICAL RANGE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to solidify the recovery of tigers in Thailand's Dong Phayayen-Khao Yai (DPKY) Forest Complex.and secure the dispersal to connected environs including Bantaey Chhmar Protected Landscape (BCPL) in Cambodia. Project.objectives are as follows: (1) Improve strategic enforcement in DPKY and BCPL; (2) Expand monitoring to increase.understanding of tiger population dynamics and dispersal to connected habitat; and (3) Expand wider support for the conservation.of tigers, prey and biodiversity in DPKY, BCPL and the Dangrak ecological corridor.

title.narrative: RECOVERY OF TIGERS AND THEIR PREY THROUGH SMART PATROL AND HABITAT IMPROVEMENT IN THAP LAN NATIONAL PARK, THAILAND, YEAR 2 - 4.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) Strengthen the Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) patrol system in Thap Lan.through park ranger training, morale boosting support, and monitoring performance; (2) Enhance grass-based open forest areas to.boost ungulate populations in Thap Lan by using habitat management tools; (3) Estimate the density of ungulates in the core area.of Thap Lan with DISTANCE program sampling techniques; and (4) Renovate an old ranger station to a field wildlife research.station for researchers and ranger field teams.
